title: Keep your knives sharp
description: A sharp knife is safer than a dull one because it requires less force to cut through food and is less likely to slip and cause injury. Use a honing steel to keep your knives sharp between professional sharpenings.

title: Use a meat thermometer
description: Cooking meat to the right temperature is crucial for both food safety and taste. Use a meat thermometer to ensure your meat is cooked to the appropriate temperature, and let it rest for a few minutes before cutting to allow the juices to redistribute.

title: Preheat your pans
description: Preheating your pans before cooking allows food to cook evenly and prevents sticking. Heat your pan on medium-high heat for a few minutes before adding oil or food.

title: Salt your pasta water
description: Adding salt to your pasta water enhances the flavor of the pasta and helps to season the dish as a whole. Use about 1-2 tablespoons of salt per gallon of water, and add it after the water comes to a boil but before adding the pasta.

title: Properly season your cast iron pans
description: To season your cast iron pans, start by preheating your oven to 375Â°F. Rub a thin layer of vegetable oil or melted shortening all over the pan, including the outside and handle. Place the pan upside down on the oven rack and bake for 1 hour. Turn off the oven and let the pan cool completely inside. Repeat this process every few months to maintain the seasoning.
